newsitem.title: ISRAEL: IMF praises Palestinian budget law passage.
newsitem.headline: IMF praises Palestinian budget law passage.

text.p: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) on Friday welcomed the Palestinian Legislative Council's passage of its first budget law.

The 88-member council approved a 13-article budget law this week, setting the framework within which annual budgets are laid out. Council members said they expected an $866 million budget for 1997 to be approved next week.
The budget, presented to the council for the first time since the Palestinian Authority was established in 1994, was submitted late for a year that runs from January to December.

"The IMF is extremely happy that the budget law has been passed by the Palestinian Legislative Council...It's an extremely important step since it is the first budget to be approved," Salam Fayyad, IMF director in the West Bank and Gaza, told Reuters.
"The next step now in 1997 is strict implementation of this law. It's key for fiscal conversions to continue as planned," he said.
Fayyad said projected revenues for the 1997 budget were $814 million while expenditures were set at $866 million.
A $51.8 million deficit is forecast. Both the Palestinian Authority and the IMF say they expect donor countries to cover the deficit.
Fayyad said the Palestinian Authority had already secured external financing of $10 million for the budget deficit.
Last year's deficit was $95 million. Fayyad said the deficit reduction was because of improved revenue administration.
The 1997 budget encompasses only current expenditures, excluding capital expenditures which depend on funds pledged by donor countries.
Fayyad said the IMF was looking forward to working with the Palestinian Authority on the 1998 budget, which he said he hoped would be approved early next year.

"We also look forward to beginning work on next year's budget so it would not be delayed. We also hope that for 1998 there would be a budget encompassing both capital and current expenditures," he said.
